course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Analytical Chemistry
course.description: Fundamental and practical aspects of chemical analysis, including titrimetric, electrical, optical and mass spectroscopic methods, analytical separations by chromatography. For students in the programs under the four-year degree that designate this course as required course/specified elective only.
course.prerequisites: CHEM 1010 OR CHEM 1020

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Okay but could be improved.
reviews.comment_content:
An introductory course for non-chemistry major students, including BCB, BIOT, ENVS, CENG, CBME, etc. Very diverse backgrounds. This somehow shows that analytical chemistry can be widely applied to lots of areas.

Some parts of the content in this course overlap with those of CHEM1030, so it is suggested you have taken CHEM1030 before registering this course even though it is not listed as a prerequisite. Basic statistics background (MATH2411/ISOM2500/SOSC1100) is also highly recommended if you wanna better understand the concept of the confidence interval (including the distribution of sample means, the Central Limit Theorem, and how you devise the sampling plan) and the rationale behind these statistical tests (Type-I/II errors in hypothesis testing and the rejection rules).

But don't worry if you don't have any statistics background. The statistics taught in this course is basically a series of standard procedures and you can skim through the part even though you don't understand the details behind.

Before midterm
ğŸ”· 1 Introduction to Analytical Chemistry
ğŸ”¶ 2 Fundamentals of Analytical Chemistry
ğŸ”¶ 3 Errors and Uncertainty
ğŸ”¶ 4 Statistics
ğŸ”¶ 5 Standardization
ğŸ”¶ 6 Sampling
ğŸ”· 7 Gravimetry
ğŸ”¶ğŸ”· 8 Titration

After midterm
ğŸ”¶ğŸ”· 10 Spectroscopy
ğŸ”· 11 Chromatography
ğŸ”· 12 Mass Spectrometry
ğŸ”¶ğŸ”· 13 Electrochemistry

ğŸ”¶ Calculation-based
ğŸ”· Principle-based

Chapters 1 to 6 are mostly numerical methods for experimental design and data analysis, and from chapter 7 onwards they are analytical methods commonly used. Most of the parts are in fact quite conceptually demanding and needs some time to digest. Note that understanding of concepts is more important than calculation. You've probably seen similar stuff of acid-base titration and electrochemistry in CHEM1030 previously, but new things in the more applied aspect, such as EDTA titration, amperometry, potentiometry and cyclic voltammetry, are also introduced.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Yan He is indeed a very passionate lecturer. He came back to UST for teaching after his own start-up failed. With such an experience, he is unlike many other professors who only stay in the ivory tower for the whole life. He is also dedicated to improving our presentation skills, and he let students volunteer for a presentation on any topic they like in front of the whole class. But at last only 1 student did it. :(

His teaching is generally good in science school's standard. But I really think some parts of it could be improved. In the beginning he spent slightly too much time explaining the easy part of significant figures, and then rushed a bit too fast in the more difficult statistics part, which I believe most students don't have any background at all. But the good thing is that he used iPRS to test our knowledge in class and assigned homework to let us have more practice (though he obviously doesn't know how to use the iPRS system lol). These are quite effective in helping us understand the concept and how we'll possibly make mistakes in the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
âœï¸ Assignments x 2: 10%

âœï¸ Non-cumulative final exam: 45%

Exams consist of MCQs, calculation problems and short questions.

Midterm:
Mean = 70. SD = 16.
A lot of calculation problems. Generally not difficult as soon as you have understood the content enough, had enough practice and done the paper CAREFULLY. Pay special attention to acid-base equilibria calculation and EDTA titration which are the most difficult parts of the midterm. Calculation of propagation of uncertainty is tedious, but if you're careful then you'll be fine. A few principle-based questions are also asked, e.g.

ğŸ”· What are the 2 reasons why Mg is commonly used in EDTA titration?
ğŸ”· Does a more acidic environment favor the liquid-liquid extraction?

Final:
Mean = 69.7. SD unknown.
More difficult as it required us to explain in detail the principles of these analytical methods in our own words. When marking our papers the TA's have a habit of randomly deducting 1 or 2 marks from each question... Just try your best to score partial credits for each question.

A few examples:
ğŸ”· Explain the difference between atomic absorption and emission spectroscopy. Why is the inductively coupled plasma the most suitable atomization method for atomic emission spectroscopy?
ğŸ”· Why does atomic emission give clear and discrete spectral lines while molecular emission gives a spectrum with continuous wavelengths?
ğŸ”· Why is the bandwidth of the emission spectrum broader than that of the hollow-cathode lamp emission?
ğŸ”· Explain how column chromatography works, including the roles of stationary phase and mobile phase.
ğŸ”· What are the 3 pieces of information we can obtain from the mass-spectrometry spectrum, other than the mass of the molecule?
ğŸ”· Explain how the 3-electrode design of the glucose meter can eliminate the effect of interfering biological species during the detection of blood glucose level.

You either understand the whole thing or flunk the whole final exam.

You've still got 2 to 3 calculation problems in the final though, mostly involving:
ğŸ”¶ Beer's law
ğŸ”¶ Nernst equation
ğŸ”¶ Boltzmann distribution formula for fraction of electrons in excited states

I got 96/100 (+1.6 SD) in the midterm and 86.5/100 in the final.
ğŸ’¯ Final grade: A+

Better than expected. I thought I didn't do that well in the final.
reviews.comment_workload:
Prof Yan may take attendance when he feels the attendance rate is not high. And it is indeed highly recommended you attend his lectures because he will lay emphasis on important concepts, and you'll know the parts of the ppts you really need to study. Otherwise, you may end up revising a lot of unimportant and messy details that are distracting and not required at all.

The 2 assignments before the midterm is a little bit of workload, but we do need them to practice the calculation. No more assignments will be distributed after the midterm as the content becomes more principle-based. Btw assignments are credited upon submission, i.e. you can submit any crap to get full score.

reviews.author: illiteracy
reviews.title: Analytical Chemistry
reviews.comment_content:
Standard introductory analytical chemistry topics.  I like the way Henry also included a light touch of statistics.

Before Mid Term [calculation-based]:
Basic statistics (very basic statistical inferences, student t, t-test, f-test)
Classical methods (gravimetric and titrimetric analyses, separation methods and calculation)

After Mid Term [principle-based]:
Instrumental methods (spectroscopy, chromatography, electrochemistry, mass spectrometry)
reviews.comment_teaching:
One of the best professors I have ever met in UST.  

Extremely passionate and dedicated to students.  Explains important concepts over and over and over again to make sure everyone understands them.  He also makes the lectures less boring by being humorous and sharing us his past experiences.

Gives review powerpoints and lectures before exams, sends you important questions from students and his answers.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 exams (M.C. and short questions),
3 mandatory assignments (you'll get the marks as long as you hand in them, they are not graded but model answers will be posted)

Mid Term: above ~1.8 s.d.
Final: above ~ 1 s.d.
Final grade: ~92/100, A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Really not that much.  The assignments will help you understand the topics better and prepare you for exams (assuming you're doing them on your own).

There is also an optional presentation, but only 1 student did this last semester lol.

Exams are easy and straight-forward.  You just need to be careful avoiding careless mistakes.

reviews.author: JJLL
reviews.title: A good course
reviews.comment_content:
This is the course for students who are interested in Analytical chemistry. The content is similar to 2310.
The structure is as follows:
1. Basic Tools of Analytical Chemistry
2. Evaluating Analytical Data: Errors and propagation of uncertainty
3. Evaluating Analytical Data: Statistics
4. Standardizing Analytical Methods
5. Collecting and Preparing Samples
6. Gravimetric and Combustion Analysis
7.Titrimetric Methods (Acid and bases)
8.Titrimetric Methods (ComplexationTitration and Redox titration)
9. Spectroscopic method: (Overview and Absorption Spectroscopy)
10. Spectroscopic method: (Atomic Emission and Absorption Spectrometry)
11. Chromatography
12. Mass Spectrometry
13. Electrolysis and Electrochemistry-based analysis

The midterm exam covers Ch 1-9, while the final exam would cover Ch 10-13 as well as analytical methods in all chapters.

This course introduces the basic information of analytical chemistry, from mathematical knowledge like statistics, standardization calibration curves, to chemical knowledge like titration, spectrometry and electrochemistry. Students who attend the course are advised to have a solid background in statistics and chemistry.

Undergraduates who attend the class can have a slight advantage in making use of instrumental analysis. For example, students can acknowledge that spectrometry can detect groups of metal ions in heavy water. Having a solid understanding, they can analyse the samples at ease.

However, the materials in this course are a little bit underwhelming. The context should have put more emphasis on principle on instruments, rather than briefly points out the advantages and disadvantages of each of them.
reviews.comment_teaching: Overall, professor Yan successfully put his passion and insight into the course. He makes us appreciate the analytical chemistry and learn what are the criteria to be a good chemist.
reviews.comment_grading:
The online exam is well set, and the grading system is satisfactory. However, the exam questions can be a little bit more challenging and unfamiliar so that flexible thinking can be promoted.

Format: MC only
Grading:
Midterm: 42/44, Average: 30.6 SD: 6.5
Final: 43/45, Average: 32.1 SD: 6.1
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. Most exam questions can be found in the homework and lecture notes.

reviews.author: Eclipse
reviews.title: Pretty decent course to take
reviews.comment_content:
Since this course was basically made for students that are not in chemistry major, that require the knowledge of analytical chemistry, the contents are more general in comparison to that of CHEM 2310. Content list includes:

Uncertainty
Statistics (t-test, f-test, etc.)
Standardization
Samples
Gravimetry
Titration
Spectroscopy
Chromatography
Mass Spec
Electrochemistry

If you have done IB/A-level before, and have done analytical chemistry as part of your syllabus, then this subject would be a lot more bearable for you. Many of the contents covered are already covered in the IB analytical chemistry section.
reviews.comment_teaching: Since the teaching is in form of lectures, it is pretty much the most standard course in this area. The prof is very nice, so if you approach him for clarification/other questions, he answers it very patiently. His accent is not that bad, it was not a trouble understanding his lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
I wouldn't say it has the very best of grading, but it is definitely about the average in the school.

The grading was divided into:

Homework and Assignment - 10%
Mid-term - 45%
Final - 45%

The grading for my case was:

Mid term - 93.5 ~ 1.3 SD Mean 75/ SD 14
Final - 89 ~ 1.2 SD Mean 71/ SD 15
Attendance and homework - 10

Total I got A. Sounds about reasonable with the above mentioned grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
Except for the 2 assignments that he requires the students to do, the only thing that you have to do is to prepare for the exams. If you have been listening in class, there should not be too much of a problem preparing for the exams.

There is this one lesson that the prof requires you to attend, to get the attendance grade. So long as you attend it, you get the full attendance mark, so do attend it.

reviews.author: RichardY
reviews.comment_content: The content is not that rich in my opinion. Before midterm, the content mostly covers the basics of analytical chemistry  (concept of uncertainty and statistics) and basic techniques to conduct chemical analysis (calibration, sampling, gravimetric and titrimetric analysis). The next part covers instrumental analysis (spectroscopy, chromatography, mass spectrometry and electrochemistry) at the introductory level.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Henry Yan is good in terms of teaching. Sometimes he made some mistakes but he is very responsible and would always make up for his mistakes. However, the thing I don't like is that the exams are not designed well to be honest, many questions are just direct copying from the notes/textbook. Also, the level of difficulty is way too low so that it simply differentiates people based on cautiousness or whether they have read the notes instead of testing people on the thorough understanding of the content.
reviews.comment_grading: I got overall 95% A+ (class mean ~ 75%, SD ~ 15). Since the mean is quite high, you need to be very careful in doing the exams in order to secure an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very small, I only studied for two or three days before exams. Also, he uploaded all the answers of the assignments before submission deadline and so you can just copy it if you do not know how to do it.

reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is pretty good actually. You can tell the prof likes what he teaches and is good at what he does. He also includes a whole bunch of mini anecdotes which help you remember the concepts in an interesting way.
He also uses the lecture before midterms or finals to review all the content and examples
BUT
in the middle he made a very stressful situation for students by trying to suddenly change the grading scheme to make everyone do his presentation competition. Luckily, he listened to the students and did not proceed with making us do the presentations.
I think maybe he should contact the school to send a mass email if he wants to make the competition more successful, not talk for the majority of the lecture about it in a course that people are taking just to satisfy some course requirements.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good la
Some very smart people might find it unfair but if you are bad at chem like me then it is good.
I got barely 50 overall in midterm (less than mean, thought I would fail at that point) and then a bit over SD for final (because it was very easy) and got B. I was expecting F so it is satisfactory for me.
Just one annoying thing is the attendance system, he picks names at random to check at end of lectures but its annoying to get picked all the time even though the people who dont actually come never get picked. Should just do iPRS in middle of class so it is fair and people cant just come at the end to check attendance.
For assignment, just submit anything for mark.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much, just make sure to take time to review all the techniques.
For midterm, need some chemistry sense so do examples questions in slides ww
JUST MEMORISE EVERYTHING for final

reviews.author: LSJU
reviews.title: Feedback of CHEM2311
reviews.comment_content: You can read other students' comments.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor teaches very well. And very, very enthusiastic, one of the most enthusiastic professors I've seen in UST. And the content he teaches is very practical. The professor will emphasize the important points.
reviews.comment_grading: Truth be told, I think grading is rather average. I think it has to do with the design of the exam. The questions in the second midterm were a bit strange, so many students who had studied well didn't get good grades. The final exam was designed to be too easy, so it didn't make the gap between students. In the end, everyone's grades were exceptionally high.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost no workload. Reviewing before exams is also particularly easy because the professor will tell students all the important knowledge.

reviews.author: Anisha
reviews.title: interesting course with excellent professor
reviews.comment_content: Before the midterms, it's all basically statistics and tests that we use in experiments in the laboratory. Most of them were covered in high school and you need to learn of a few more new ones. After midterms, its all conceptual topics which are really not that difficult to grasp if you have good high school chemistry and physics background.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Yan is an excellent teacher and a huge fan of Breaking Bad like myself (lol). He engages the students with the topics using personal experiences and also real world examples. After some lectures, he sometimes takes short MC quizzes on the iPRS to clear out our concepts as well as take the attendance if he thinks attendance looks low. He is also very approachable and responds quickly to emails on canvas. The professor even gave a list of formulae to memorize and things to remember for the exams.
There are lecture videos available too if you want and I gotta say they were extremely helpful right before exams to revise if you had not showed up for class once or twice.
reviews.comment_grading:
For midterms, mean was about 70% and sd was 10. For finals mean was 68% and sd was a bit lower than, I'm not exactly sure of the value. There were also 2 homework which you would get full marks in if you submit on time.

I got 91% for mids and 90% for finals. submitted my homework on time.
Overall percentage was 90 and grade was A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is really low. Just attend and pay attention to the lectures, do the homework by yourself and its guaranteed you'll do well in the exams.

reviews.author: zlong
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm is about statistics. Topics include significant figures, universal units, uncertainty, errors, statistics (mean, s.d., confidence interval, t-test, F-test, Grubbs test), standardization, acid and base, sample collection, Gravimetric and Combustion Analysis, Titrimetric Methods. More calculations are involved in midterm.

Final is about explanation of concepts. Topics include acid-base titration, EDTA titration, Gravimetric analysis, TGA, Elemental analysis or combustion analysis, UV-Vis absorption spectroscopy, Photoluminescence spectroscopy, Atomic emission spectroscopy, Atomic absorption spectroscopy, Chromatography (GC, LC, HPLC, GPC, column chromatography), Mass spec, GC-MS, LC-MS, Potentiometry, Amperometry, Cyclic voltammetry. Underlying principles of each diagnostic methods should be well understood.

These topics is closely related to our everyday life and are quite interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture videos are provided.

reviews.author: ym7135
reviews.title: Best Chemistry course @UST for now
reviews.comment_content:
This course is like the starting step to further courses like instrumental analysis or other analytical techniques courses. It is made intentionally for non-chemistry major students.

I have to say this course really provides a lot of great info and skills to anyone doing research (even in biochemistry); the professor has chosen topics and experimental techniques that are very accessible and overall the course flows very well (even though some people complained it was math heavy, but the math parts were actually useful even for other majors, especially stats) The chapters covered were:

1. Basic tools - e.g. using s.f. and decimal places, analyzing results
2. Uncertainty and propagation.
3. Statistics (T-tests, F-test, Grubb's test ...)
4. Standardization (single, multi-point, standard addition and internal standard)
5. Sampling and statistics
6. Gravimetry (Gravitational analysis, TGA and elemental analysis)
7. Titration (Acid base and EDTA)
[MID TERMS]

8. Spectroscopy (UV-Vis, Abs and Transmittance, atomic absorption and emission)
9. Chromatography (LC, GC, HPLC)
10. Mass Spectrometry (5-6 types)
11. Electrochemistry and its applications (e.g. pH meter, glucose meter, band gap...)
[FINALS]

Overall, the content was mainly about how to collect and process data for conclusions, and the experimental approaches and analysis for very specific measurements ... something like that. It does flow very well from IB Chemistry, but do expect that you have to do calculations in every chapter.

Although the finals is non-cumulative, you may need to recongize some techniques from pre-midterm (but only 1-2). DO NOT READ THE TEXTBOOK (he even suggested against using the textbook), as long as you watch the lecture videos or attend class that is more than good enough.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is a very enthusiastic professor, he knows and can make people understand his content very easily. Although he is from the mainland, he has worked in many industries in the US and his English is very good (Slight American accent lol).

Sometimes he deviates from the content a little bit (still related) to talk a bit about his research or previous experiences in labs/industries, or the news; students actually find it quite interesting, especially when he makes it funny!

Other benefits of his teaching:
- He has iPRS questions during class - guess what, these ended up being the exam questions (aka 40% of mid term MCQs were already given in class lol)
- To be honest he indirectly answers every exam question in the paper (especially the finals, all the essay writing was directly wait he said in class).
- He uses a projector to show his math working/drawings (a lot of these calculations are exactly what will show up in the exams)
- Relates a lot of his content to real cases, so it makes the content a lot more meaningful.

Flaws?
Only one, he has too many slides! a lot are just there 'for information' and he doesn't spend time on it (not asked in the exam). Just look at the slides which he spends time on for exams - I feel like he is doing this so only students who attend class/ watch lecture videos knows what to study
reviews.comment_grading:
45% Mid-terms (There are 2 mid-terms - one was more MCQ and some calculations, the other was statistical tests and data analysis; the mid term date was very late - around 6th and 11th April)

45% Finals (Around 12 MCQ, 5 True or False, 10 short answer - some involving calculations, some purely an essay e.g. explain the mechanism of a glucose sensor, why does organic molecules have a broad band absorption; and the last part was basically matching the technique to the description)

9% Homework - There will be 2 homework assignments (textbook questions) were you have to write out, scan and submit on canvas - one was before March, one was right before mid term. This 9% is only based on if you submitted, not how correct you are. For the second hw he even put out model answers before the deadline (ikr, really strange? we could just copy??)

1% Attendance - He will take attendance in class sometimes (via iPRS).

Issue with this course is that people do well - homework and attendance is full for almost everyone, mid-term and final average was higher than 70%.

Overall mid-term had easier questions (because more topics were covered), while finals had harder and in-depth questions on less topics.

My Grades:
100% (10/10) for hw and attendance - easy part
100% for mid-term
88% for finals
Overall score: 94%, Grade: A+
P.S. I think somewhere around 94% is the cut-off for an A+, a friend who got 92% got an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderate workload, mainly just preparing for exams.

His lecture videos and iPRS questions is exactly whats in the exam, there were no surprises.

Homework took no more than 2 hours each to complete.

reviews.comment_content:
This courses is slightly different from CHEM 2310, as this one is meant for non-Chem majors (like ENVS, etc.), so the content is more general and doesn't go as deep as 2310 in the topics. Topics include:
Uncertainty
Statistics (t-test, f-test, etc.)
Standardization
Samples
Gravimetry
Titration
Spectroscopy
Chromatography
Mass Spec
Electrochemistry

The content is quite interesting and not too difficult or complex to understand even without much chemistry background (only General Chemistry I is a prerequisite). This course is a requirement for courses like Environmental Chem and Separation Science.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Yan is one of the best professors I have had. He is extremely passionate, thorough, clear and very helpful. He always tries to make his lectures fun and explains the relevance of what he is teaching to us. He provides a lot of support outside lectures too, he is always open to any questions even on the last day before the exam, and keeps uploading helpful documents like Q&A from other students, list of equations to memorize, etc.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 45%
Final: 45%
Homework (2): 3+3 = 6%
Attendance (only 1 session): 4%

The grading is a little difficult because most people get quite high marks so it is quite difficult to get into A range.

I got ~0.6 SD above mean in both midterm and final (both had mean around 70%), and full in homework and attendance (almost everyone gets full) = B+ grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
2 homework sets, they are quite easy but do take a lot of time as each has around 30+ problems. But they are distributed over the entire term. Attendance is taken only at 1 practice session before the midterm which counts for 4%, but it's worth attending the lectures anyway because of the professor (although lectures are recorded and uploaded).
The exam do not need too much preparation. There is not a lot of memorization required, more understanding and application of the concepts, and quite a lot of calculations especially for the midterm.

reviews.author: diudiu
reviews.comment_content:
The course content can largely be divided into two parts, separated by the midterm examination.
Before the midterm, the contents are more calculations-oriented, as the course revolves around basic statistical tools like T-test, F-test etc.; Also included here are methods for standardization, sampling, and basic analyses like gravimetric analysis and titrimetric analysis.
After the midterm, the focus shifts to understanding the concepts underlying analytical methods like spectroscopy, electrochemistry and chromatography. (in which understanding = recitation in exams T.T)
The course contents are generally not difficult to understand and some even coincided with CHEM1030. Explains the (unfortunately) high mean in the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not the most proficient English speaker, but largely makes up for it with his humour and passion.
He is very devoted to his teaching and would post Q&As as well as tips for the exams on canvas. He also tries and make sure every student understands what he taught, and would devote at least 20 minutes each lecture to recap the previous lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
45% midterm
45% final
10% 2 Assignments + Attendance of a practice session
Basically everyone gets the full 10% for the assignments and attendance, since the assignments are not actually graded (lol) and as long as you've submitted them, you will get full credit.

The mean for the midterm and final exams are 75 and 70 respectively, while the SDs are ~15 for both exams.
Needless to say, there are people that somehow snatched 100.

For me, I got >1SD in midterm and 1.5 SD in final for an overall score of 91% --> A
reviews.comment_workload:
Practically no workload, as the course contents are quite easy and the assignments are not graded.
To get a good grade in this course, you just need to
(i) be very careful in exams (essentially what differentiates A/A+)
(ii) memorise those slides after the midterm (non-accumulative :D)
(iii) practice (sporadically)(ok not really)
